data.title: Wes Montgomeryâ€™s Smokinâ€™ at the Half Note: The Evolution of an Album: Part 1 â€“ Jazz Guitar Life
data.text:
Jazz Guitar Life thanks Dr. Wayne Goins for his invaluable service to the Jazz Guitar Community â€“ both past and present â€“ in his roles as a player, educator and writer/researcher and we are especially grateful for his insight into this iconic album. When asked about which album â€œhas it allâ€, Pat Metheny answered: â€œI would pick Smokinâ€™ at the Half Note. Wes Montgomery and the Wynton Kelly Trio live in NYC at a club called the Half Note. Everything about it attracts me. The melodies, the feel, the ingenuity of all the players, the interaction, the sound. Everything.â€ (source) Dig into this article to learn more. Enjoy! â€“ Lyle Robinson â€“ Jazz Guitar Life

Thank you and your patronage is greatly appreciated regardless if you buy me a coffee or not ğŸ™‚ â€“ Lyle Robinson

Wes Montgomeryâ€™s Smokinâ€™ at the Half Note: The Evolution of an Album

SIDE 1: THE INSTRUMENTAL TRACKS

By now, itâ€™s become an all too familiar event among jazz guitarists around the world: One of the greatest documented performances ever to take place in modern history occurred in June of 1965 when Wes Montgomery played at The Half Note jazz nightclub in New York City. He was backed by the supporting rhythm section trio of the Miles Davis bandâ€”pianist Wynton Kelly, bassist Paul Chambers, and drummer Jimmy Cobb. It wasnâ€™t the first time Wes had performed with this all-star backing groupâ€”heâ€™d previously recorded a performance almost exactly three years to the dayâ€”captured â€˜liveâ€™ at Tsubo in Berkeley, California on June 25, 1962, with tenor saxophonist Johnny Griffin in tow. Released on Riverside Records, Full House [RLP 434 in mono, RS 9434 stereo] represents a stunning performance for a group that hadnâ€™t worked together before.

While that album was hailed as a phenomenal success by both fellow musicians and ardent music critics alike, their crowning achievement was yet to arrive. Over time, the album has become nothing less than a staple in the library of all serious fans of jazz guitar. Indeed, Smokinâ€™ at the Half Note has been routinely identified as one of the quintessential recordings that easily falls in the categorized as â€œessential listeningâ€ among jazz enthusiasts. Pat Metheny, among others, has gone on record claiming that upon his first encounter with listening to the album, it literally altered his life. In the liner notes to the double disc CD, Impressions: The Verve Jazz Sides,Metheny is quoted as citing â€˜Smokinâ€™â€™ as â€œthe absolute greatest jazz guitar album ever made. Itâ€™s also the record that taught me how to play.â€

There have been scores of articles written about the impact and the influence of Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note, mainly revered for the dazzling single-note wizardry and sophisticated chord solos weaved by Wes on each of those tracks from the album. There isnâ€™t any real need to offer yet another in-depth analysis of how Wes built his amazing and often imitated three-tiered solo structures that we as jazz guitar enthusiasts have all come to know and love. But what I really wanna know is: How many pieces have been written about the evolution of the album itself? It might not be such common knowledge among fans of the LP to be aware that this album has gone through no less than five iterations over the years, with some slight (and other not-so-slight) alterations that make each one of them just a bit different from the other.

To start at the beginning, of course we remember the first time we saw that classic Verve coverâ€”a beautiful Lake Placid blue with the neon-red glow of the clubâ€™s â€œJazz Nightlyâ€ street sign, the albumâ€™s title above it in thick, baby-blue capital letters. One of the most interesting things about that cover, at first glance, is that it reads as an album listed under Wynton Kellyâ€™s name. And in contrast to the albumâ€™s main title in thick baby blue wording, thereâ€™s the thin white font of capitalized letters: The â€œWynton Kelly Trio,â€ underlined with Wes Montgomeryâ€™s name underneath it. Now, thisâ€”at least in my mindâ€”somehow always felt almost as an afterthought. In any case, most guitarists still refer to it as a â€œWes Montgomeryâ€ album. Once you opened the panels of the cardboard gatefold sleeves that held the vinyl platter, you caught the first glimpse of the black and white photos inside.

This initial 1965 release (in both mono and stereo) had the five songs that we are all familiar withâ€”â€œNo Blues,â€ â€œIf You Could See Me Now,â€ â€œUnit 7,â€ â€œFour On Six,â€ and â€œWhatâ€™s New.â€ And although the albumâ€™s title subtly implies the entire album is recorded live at the Half Note, alas, it is not: Although those five songsâ€”among several othersâ€”were performed on the June 24th gig, the last three tunes were recorded again later in September 22 at Rudy Van Gelderâ€™s studio in Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey and inserted on the album as a replacement for the live versions. Only the first two tracks, â€œNo Bluesâ€ and â€œIf You Could See Me Nowâ€ represented the live â€œsmokinâ€™â€ session from June 24, which, at least to me, makes the album feel just slightly misleading. Whatâ€™s more shocking, however, is that once you hear the live versions, you wonder just what in the world was Creed Taylor thinking by holding back the â€œrealâ€ versionsâ€”whose rightful place should have been on this album from the very start?

Most of us were unaware that two days later, even more music was recorded for posterity, which included five live Half Note performances: â€œWillow Weep For Me,â€ â€œPortrait of Jennie,â€ â€œSurrey With The Fringe On Top,â€ â€œOh, You Crazy Moon,â€ and â€œMisty,â€ all recorded on June 24. The specific date for the recording of a sixth live tune, â€œImpressions,â€ was only identified as being captured somewhere during the week-long stretch of the bandâ€™s road gig that lasted between June 22nd and 27th. But we never heard any of those swinging six tracks until more than three years after, when they appeared in late December 1968. By then, Wes had jumped ship (a year earlier) and joined Herb Alpertâ€™s A&M Records, which went on to produce a bevy of commercial albums that were very much MOR (â€œmiddle of the roadâ€) products aimed at audiences who preferred music that was less extreme than the hard bop music Wes was best known for delivering.

It is very likely this material surfaced and was released by Verve in December because Wes died only months earlier in June 15, 1968, at the age of forty-five, and Creed Taylorâ€”the very same man that deemed this music previously unacceptable to the public at the time it was originally recordedâ€”now suddenly found it more urgent to unveil. This leads us to the second iteration of the Half Note material that Wes fans recognize as Willow Weep For Me [V6-8765]. Released on Verve Records, the album boasts seven tracks of unreleased live material, including the title track along with â€œPortrait of Jennie,â€ â€œImpressionsâ€ â€œFour On Six,â€ â€œSurrey With The Fringe On Top,â€ â€œOh You Crazy Moon,â€ and â€œMisty.â€ But to add more intrigue and confusion to the mix, four of those tunes were altered as an afterthoughtâ€”with Verve clearly taking a page out of the A&M labelâ€™s playbook to appeal to the MOR crowd. Creed Taylor had highly-reputable conductor and orchestrator Claus Ogerman come in and provide a brass and woodwind section which overdubbed parts to â€˜Willow,â€™ â€˜Portrait,â€™ â€˜Crazy,â€™ and â€˜Mistyâ€™ on October 8, 1968 in New York City. This, however leads to the need for the third version of the â€˜Smokinâ€™â€™ tracks that Wes fans and jazz guitar purists were quietly hoping for.

This version appears in 1976 when a collection of performances of Wes Montgomery were released as part of double album, Verve Small Group Recordings [Verve VE2 2513] which has eleven songs on four sides highlighting Wes with the trio, along with other tracks featuring drummer Grady Tate, conga player Ray Barretto, and Hammond B3 organist Jimmy Smith. The real significance of this collection involves the versions of â€˜Willow,â€™ â€˜Portrait,â€™ and â€˜Mistyâ€™ which were finally releasedâ€”for the first time on vinylâ€”with the Claus Ogerman wind/brass overdubs removed.

A major turning point came when an impressive Japanese pressing arrived in December 1988 with not only the contents of the five original tracks from â€˜Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note (which could, theoretically, now be referred to as Volume 1) but a whole lot more. In this fourth iteration, it took the best of all three previous versions by doing three things: 1) It kept the two live tracks from Volume 1; 2) It added the seven live tracks from â€˜Willowâ€™; and 3) it included the Ogerman-stripped versions of those tracks from the â€™76 small group LP. These nine tracks are what comprises Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note Vol. 2 [J28J25117], thus it appears we are one step closer to what the live setlist may have sounded like! This was quickly followed by yet another Japanese remastered edition that appeared in 1990 [POCJ-1902]. It should be noted that both these Japanese issues similar in content and format (I therefore donâ€™t count this one as a new iteration). One relatively minor-yet-significant revelation does deserve mention regarding the fourth iteration: Just as â€˜Willow,â€™ â€˜Portrait,â€™ and â€˜Mistyâ€™ were freed upon release of the 1976 small group recordings, â€œOh, You Crazy Moonâ€ was the fourth song finally freed of the brass/wind of Ogerman, heard for the first time on this CD.

And then thereâ€™s yet a fifth renditionâ€”the two-disc set in 1995 by Polygram Records (who now owned the Verve masters) , Impressions: The Verve Jazz Sides [Verve 314 521 690-2]. This CD set boasts quite a bit of material, with a delightful array of selected cuts from several Wes Montgomery albums, including tracks from Movinâ€™ Wes, Goinâ€™ Out of My Head, California Dreaminâ€™, and Jimmy & Wes: The Dynamic Duo, and Further Adventures of Jimmy and Wes, Tequila, and Just Walkinâ€™. These twelve tracks cover the span of his tenure with Verveâ€”but this material is just an appetizer for what fans were really waiting for. The bulk and highlight of the double disc set involves the next thirteen tracks, which essentially puts volumes 1 and 2 of the Half Note material under one roof.

The remastered sound quality is incredible, so superior to previous versionsâ€”the clarity and separation of instruments is astounding. Jimmy Cobbâ€™s drums and Paul Chambersâ€™ bass are center, with Wesâ€™ guitar in the right ear, and Wyntonâ€™ Kellyâ€™s piano is in the left ear. The audience enthusiastic applause is also quite audible. The last three tracks of the first disc, along with the entire second disc of the with an added bonusâ€”the originally edited version of Wesâ€™s June 26 performance of â€œSurrey With The Fringe On Topâ€ on the Verve 1968 â€˜Willowâ€™ album is on track 14 of the first disc, but we finally get to hear the reconstructed and restored version [track 15.] Hereâ€™s another little bonus: Since this collection has all the live versions and the tracks from the Van Gelder studio session, you get two versions of â€œFour on Six.â€

An even greater bonus is the added transcription of the dual interview given by Howard Mandel to none other than Russell Malone and Mark Whitfield, as they listen to an advance copy of the â€˜Impressionsâ€™ album thatâ€™s being described here. Their detailed comments regarding Wes Montgomeryâ€™s musical career and influence are thoroughly engaging, with both gentlemen providing a wealth of rare and insightful information. In November 2021, yet another remastered issue of Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note appeared (the Verve material now marketed and distributed by Universal Music) under the title of The Complete Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note Vol. 2 [UCCU-8200].

Then there was the sixth rendition of Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note released by Verve [B0003934-02]â€”an impressive 2005 release that basically capitalizes on the work collected in the â€˜Impressionsâ€™ CD, but eschewing the bulk of Disc 1 and only focusing on the â€˜Half Note material from volumes 1 and 2, including the stripped overdubs. The physical packaging of the album is most impressive, which features previously unreleased photos on the tray card and booklet of Wes at the Half Note gig for which the music is famous, not to mention the highly-detailed liner notes that inspired me to do more detective work to further chronicle the historical sequence of these various releases (which eventually led to the writing of this article.)

Even more pleasurable, though, is being able to hearâ€”for the first timeâ€”the lengthier versions of dialogue from the emcee Alan Grant. His comments really add to the feeling of â€œbeing thereâ€ when listening to this rendition of the live albumâ€”complete with glasses clinking and enthusiastic applause supplied by the audience during the exciting, unfiltered performance. Grantâ€™s banter is warm and inviting as he introduces Wes and the band individually after their performance of â€œWhatâ€™s New.â€ Previously unreleased on any of the earlier iterations, Grant provides a beautiful verbal backdrop to create context for the recording: The quartet is performing as a part of the â€œPortraits In Jazzâ€ series; the show is being taped live each Friday night for the WABC radio show; he informs the listeners that Wes has just returned to America from a successful European tour with the this band; he announces the venueâ€™s location at 289 Hudson Street (the corner of Hudson and Spring.)

It is also wonderful to hear Wes laugh as he exchanges delightful banter with Grant during the course of the evening as they work their way through the setlist. Grant asks Wes what tunes will they be playing, then introduces the tunes over the airwavesâ€”just listen to the dialogue before the start of â€œWillow Weep For Me.â€ While other versions are seven minutes and thirty seconds, this one is 9â€™08â€; at end of the tune, Grant talks about Wes appearing there until Sunday, and goes straight into the comment for the airwaves, â€œA pretty ballad now, a â€˜Portrait of Jennyâ€¦â€™

For all the other versions of this music, his dialogue gets cut off or faded out in the engineering room for the sake of saving space, as if itâ€™s not worthy of preserving. But here, he gets more time and space as he is heard acknowledging both the beginning and end of several songs. He casually introduces â€œOh You Crazy Moonâ€ and â€œMisty;â€ when this particular song ends, Grant is absolutely elated with Montgomeryâ€™s playing, saying to the audience, â€œhow about that?â€ then, inquisitively to Montgomery, â€œWhat were you doing?â€¦Wes?â€

At one point, Grant and Wes exchange dialogue for almost thirty seconds, as he asks Wes about the bandâ€™s routine for working out the tunes. Grant humorously informs the listeners that earlier in the broadcast the phone rang and someone had called in to make a â€œspecial requestâ€ regarding their next tune. Wes joins in as they share a laugh before the band launches into the tune, which just so happened to be â€œSurrey With The Fringe On Top.â€ Near the end of the set, you hear Alan sign off for the radio broadcast, reminding his loyal listeners to tune in â€œtomorrow at 3, stay beautifulâ€¦â€

This alone is worth the price of admission. Indeed, for the first time, we get to hear the actual exchange between the emcee and the artist. All totaled, there are thirteen minutes more on this disc than the previous iterations. For my money, this is what makes the 2005 Universal Music Verve Masters Series version of Smokinâ€™ At The Half Note the best of the bunch. So, there you have it. The legendary New York City nightclub owned and operated by Mike Canterino and his family was having a glorious moment while Wes and his band made their grand stand. The music played that night was epicâ€”worthy of no less than six versions of the show that still representsâ€”in any formatâ€”one of the greatest events in music history.

Please consider spreading the word about this article and Jazz Guitar Life by sharing this interview amongst your social media pals and please feel free to leave a comment. Weâ€™d love to hear from you ğŸ™‚

If you would like to support all the work I do on Jazz Guitar Life, please consider buying me a coffee or visiting the Jazz Guitar Life sponsors. Thank you and your patronage is greatly appreciated regardless if you buy me a coffee or not ğŸ™‚
